head.title: We Need a Global Warming Treaty With Clout; Environment Refugees

hedline.hl1: We Need a Global Warming Treaty With Clout; Environment Refugees

block.p: Your Feb. 18 editorial on global warming makes some strong points, but does not go far enough. You fail to mention, for example, that the Union of Concerned Scientists, in a recent study, estimated that carbon dioxide emissions could be cut 25 percent by 2005 and 70 percent by 2030 with a net, cumulative savings of $2.3 trillion for the United States economy. Thus, as opposed to the conventional wisdom, adopting energy-efficient technologies is good for the economy, the environment and the deficit.

To me, as someone who recently spent a year in Bangladesh, the threat of global warming has added meaning. By the mid-21st century, the predicted rise in sea level would make thousands of my friends environmental refugees, with their homes and places of work submerged by the Bay of Bengal.

Your Feb. 18 editorial on global warming makes some strong points, but does not go far enough. You fail to mention, for example, that the Union of Concerned Scientists, in a recent study, estimated that carbon dioxide emissions could be cut 25 percent by 2005 and 70 percent by 2030 with a net, cumulative savings of $2.3 trillion for the United States economy. Thus, as opposed to the conventional wisdom, adopting energy-efficient technologies is good for the economy, the environment and the deficit.

To me, as someone who recently spent a year in Bangladesh, the threat of global warming has added meaning. By the mid-21st century, the predicted rise in sea level would make thousands of my friends environmental refugees, with their homes and places of work submerged by the Bay of Bengal.

I often wonder what my children will think of me when I try to explain why the families of my Bengali friends are drowning when simple, cost-efficient technologies in the 1990's could have saved them.

For all of these economic, environmental and humanitarian reasons the Bush Administration must alter its position and sign a climate convention with strict timetables for reductions in the gases that cause global warming. ALEXANDER M. COUNTS Washington, Feb. 19, 1992 The writer is legislative director of Results, an anti-hunger lobby.
